data.title: Gérard Depardieu leads Cannes Directors Fortnight that mixes politics with pop opera
data.meta_description: The French festival strand picks provocative films about Israel, Ukraine and US society alongside a Joan of Arc electro musical, and there’s room for the debut of British director Rungano Nyoni’s film about an African girl accused of witchcraft
data.text:
The Cannes film festival has continued its emphasis on politics with the announcement of the lineup for the Directors Fortnight, the separately organised selection that runs parallel to the official festival.

The Fortnight has chosen some socially combative American films that suit the confused mood of the times: Bushwick, the Sundance hit that posits a civil war and military intervention in Brooklyn; The Florida Project, the new film from Sean Baker (Tangerine) about kids growing up in the shadow of Disney World in Florida; and another Sundance hit, the indie comedy Patti Cake$, about a poor white teen girl trying to make it as a rapper.

The line-up also includes films with a focus on explicitly political issues: Israeli director Amos Gitai (Rabin, the Last Day) brings his new documentary West of the Jordan River, a follow-up to his 1982 West Bank film Field Diary; Frost, from Lithuanian director Sharunas Bartas, features Vanessa Paradis a war reporter in the Ukraine conflict; and A Ciambra, from Mediterranea director Jonas Carpignano, which focusses on a Roma community living in Italy.

True to its mission, however, the Directors Fortnight has found room for a string of name auteurs: along with Gitai, the lineup includes Claire Denis’s Un Beau Soleil Intérieur, which opens the selection, and features Juliette Binoche and Gérard Depardieu in its ensemble cast; Bruno Dumont with his musical Jeannette: The Childhood of Joan of Arc, which contains music from electropop act Igorrr; and Abel Ferrara, who features in Alive in France, the director’s documentary about his own live concert.

The sole British director in the main line-up is Zambian-Welsh film-maker Rungano Nyoni, whose debut I Am Not a Witch – a Zambian-set film about a nine-year-old girl accused of witchcraft – has been backed by the BFI and Film4.

The Directors Fortnight runs from 18-28 May in Cannes.

Full line-up
